facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 15 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 15 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated April 15/16, 1963 of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 216 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 15 16,1963 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 216of 1961 from Original Decree.

facts.text: Respondent Club runs two race courses, one in Bombay and one at Poona.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-Club runs two race companyrses, one in Bombay and the other at Poona.

facts.text: Bombay race-course land leased by appellant Corporation to Club for 30 years commencing June 1, 1944 at annual rent Rs. 3,75,000.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in this appeal with the Bombay race-course which is companyprised of land and certain structures standing thereon. The said land is the property of the appellant-corporation given on lease to the Club for a period of 30 years companymencing from June 1, 1944 at an annual rent of Rs. 3,75,000.

facts.text: Structures on the land built by and belong to the Club.

anchor.surface_text: The said structures thereon have been built by and belong to the Club.

facts.text: Club obtained licence from Government of Maharashtra to hold race meetings at both courses, paid licence fees split between courses with Bombay share Rs. 8,66,666.

anchor.surface_text: The Club has obtained a licence from the Government of Maharashtra, permitting the Club to hold racemeetings at both the Courses and for which it paid a sum of licence fees between the two Courses in the ratio of 2 1 and thus licence fees between the two Courses in the ratio of 1 2 and thus the share of the Bombay Course came to Rs. 8,66,666.

facts.text: Rating year in question is 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: The rating year in question is 1954-55.

facts.text: Assessment based on Club's accounts for 1953-54: gross receipts Rs. 117 lacs odd, expenses Rs. 124 lacs odd, loss Rs. 7 lacs odd.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment was made on the basis of the Clubs accounts for the year 1953-54 that being the year companycluded before the assessment. According to these accounts the gross receipts of the Club came to Rs. 117 lacs and odd and the expenses . to Rs. 124 lacs and odd the accounts thus showed a loss of Rs. 7 lacs and odd.

facts.text: Deputy Municipal Commissioner disallowed expenses totalling Rs. 22 lacs odd, determined gross annual rent Rs. 13,22,430, net rateable value Rs. 11,90,187 after 10% deduction.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Municipal Commissioner who is the assessing authority disallowed expenses totalling Rs. 22 lacs and odd as having been wrongly included in the working expenses add determined. 13,22,430 as the gross annual rent and deducting therefrom the 10 percent deduction allowable under s. 15.4 of the Act assessed the net rateable value at Rs, 11,90,187.

facts.text: Club filed appeal to Small Cause Court, Bombay under s. 217.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-Club thereupon filed an appeal before the Small Cause Court, Bombay, under s. 217 of the Act.

facts.text: Club conceded items 1,2,4,5,15,16,18 rightly disallowed.

anchor.surface_text: The Club claimed in all 19 items of expenses which according to it ought to have been allowed. The Club,, however, companyceded that items 1, 2, 4, 5, 15, 16 and 18 were rightly disallowed.

facts.text: Small Cause Court totally disallowed items 3 and 9, allowed item 7 legal charges, partially allowed others.

anchor.surface_text: The Small Cause Court agreed with the Deputy Municipal Commissioner in totally disallowing expenses under Items 3 and 9. It allowed however item 7, that is, legal charges which were disallowed by the Deputy Municipal Commissioner.

facts.text: High Court determined gross rateable value Rs. 2,15,750, net Rs. 1,94,175 after 10%.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the gross rateable value of the property would after these deductions be Rs. 2,15,750 and after deducting therefrom the statutory deduction of 10 percent. the net rateable value would companye to Rs. 1,94,175

facts.text: Profits basis method employed by assessing authority and approved by Small Causes Court in prior appeals.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, the profits basis method has been adopted for the last several years and approved by the Small Causes Court in several appeals by the respondent-Club.

facts.text: Race meetings held in Bombay for 6 months in a year.

anchor.surface_text: since race-meetings were held .in Bombay for 6 months in a year only

facts.text: Licence fee total Rs. 13 lacs, Bombay allotted Rs. 8,66,666.

anchor.surface_text: For the relevant year the Club had allotted Rs, 8,66,666 out of the licence fee of Rs. 13 lacs to the Bombay race-course.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Club not pressing objection to profits basis method.

anchor.surface_text: as Counsel for the Club stated before us that he was number pressing that objection.

facts.text: Item 19 painting not pressed by Club.

anchor.surface_text: As regards Item 19, that is, painting, Counsel for the Club stated before us that he would number press that item.

facts.text: Lease excludes applicability of cl. (m) of s.108 Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: It will however be seen that the deed of lease under which the respondent-Club took the land on lease expressly excludes the applicability of cl.  in  of section 108.

facts.text: High Court confirmed 50% deduction of licence fees.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the licence fees the Club had, as aforesaid, allotted Rs. 8,66,666 to the Bombay Race Course. The Small Cause Court companyfirmed the deduction of 50 per cent only of this amount allowed by the assessing authority.

facts.text: Small Cause Court held net rateable value of Rs. 11,90,185 not excessive.

anchor.surface_text: The Small Cause Court held that the pro fits basis method employed by the assessing authority was properly employed and further held that the Club had failed to prove that the net rateable value of Rs. 11,90,185 determined by the assessing authority was excessive.

facts.text: Under lease, Club in exclusive possession of certain portions, remainder open to public except race days and training.

anchor.surface_text: under cl.  i  f  of the lease the Club is in exclusive possession of only certain portions and the remainder has to be kept open to the public except on race days and when training of horses is held.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 139 the Corporation is required to levy property taxes, tax on vehicles and animals, theatre tax and octroi.

Section 140 provides that property taxes mean water tax, halalkhor-tax and general tax of not less than 8 per cent. and not more than 26 per cent. of the rateable value of lands and buildings, education cess and betterment charges.

issues.text: the true meaning of s. 154 of the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act, III of 1888 and the correct rateable value to be assessed thereunder

anchor.surface_text: s. 154 of the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act, III of 1888 and the correct rateable value to be assessed thereunder. The respondent-Club runs two race courses, one in Bombay

issues.text: whether the profits basis method can suitably be applied in the present case

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, the profits basis method has been adopted for the last several years and approved by the Small Causes Court in several appeals by the respondent-Club. It appears that at one stage the respondent-Club raised an objection regarding its application to the present case. We need not go into the comparative merits of the different methods or into the question whether it can suitably be applied in the present case-or not

issues.text: whether expenses for upkeep and repairs of the race-course (Item No. 3) are deductible or lead to duplicate deduction with s.154(1)
whether expenses for the upkeep and repairs of the totalisator (Item 9) are deductible
whether the licence fee is deductible in full or only partly as it is for a dual purpose (licensing premises and permission to conduct races)

anchor.surface_text: For the relevant year the Club had allotted Rs, 8,66,666 out of the licence fee of Rs. 13 lacs to the Bombay race-course. Counsel urged that the Club was entitled to a deduction of Rs. 4,33,333 only as the licence was for a dual purpose, viz., for the premises as a race course and for permission to conduct race meetings on. the race-course.

issues.text: whether expenses under Items 6, 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14 should be apportioned (e.g., 7/12th) based on race meetings held only 6 months a year
whether water tax and wheel tax are deductible in full or to be apportioned
whether the net rateable value can be less than the actual contractual rent payable by the Club

arguments.claim: Expenses for upkeep and repairs of the race-course (Item No. 3) are covered by the 10% statutory deduction under s. 154(1) and further deduction would mean duplicate deduction.
arguments.court_reasoning: These are tenant's outgoings for maintaining track to earn receipts and attract attendance; not landlord's repairs covered by 10% deduction under s.154(1).

arguments.claim: Expenses for upkeep and repairs of the totalisator (Item 9) are not deductible as it is machinery whose value is not included in rating under s.154(2).
arguments.court_reasoning: Totalisator is indispensable adjunct for efficient race-course; upkeep is business outgoing contributing to receipts.

arguments.claim: Expenses under Items 6, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14 should be apportioned (e.g., 7/12th) as race meetings held only 6 months a year, remainder borne by landlord.
arguments.court_reasoning: No lease provision shifting upkeep to landlord off-season; tenant responsible year-round for track maintenance to support profit-earning.

arguments.claim: Licence fee deductible only 50% (Rs. 4,33,333) as licence serves dual purpose: licensing premises (landlord burden) and permission to conduct races (tenant burden).

anchor.surface_text: For the relevant year the Club had allotted Rs, 8,66,666 out of the licence fee of Rs. 13 lacs to the Bombay race-course. Counsel urged that the Club was entitled to a deduction of Rs. 4,33,333 only as the licence was for a dual purpose,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a race companyrse and for permission to companyduct race meetings on. the race-course. It was argued that for the first the burden would be on the les

arguments.court_reasoning: Licence under Bombay Race-Courses Act s.4 granted to Club for holding races; applied by Club; burden on conductor of races (tenant). No dual purpose evidenced.

arguments.claim: Wheel tax and water tax should be apportioned/distributed as during non-race period in Bombay, it is landlord's obligation.
arguments.court_reasoning: These are ordinary business expenses of Club; no basis for partial disallowance.

arguments.claim: Net rateable value cannot be less than actual contractual rent of Rs. 3,75,000 payable by Club; such result not contemplated under any valuation method.
arguments.court_reasoning: Hypothetical rent considers all advantages/disadvantages; lease requires Club keep portions open to public, reducing value below actual rent.

arguments.claim: Profits basis method not suitable for valuation in this case.

holdings.text: The profits basis method was properly adopted by the assessing authority for determining the rateable value.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore proceed on the footing that this method was properly adopted by the assessing authority. But that does not end the controversy, for, even. though the principles on which the profits basis method is worked out are fairly well-understood,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Method used for years, approved in prior appeals by Small Causes Court; objection withdrawn by respondent.

holdings.text: Expenses for upkeep and repairs of the race-course (Item No. 3) are proper outgoings deductible from gross receipts and not covered by the 10% statutory deduction under s.154(1).
holdings.reasoning_summary: These are tenant's business expenses to maintain track for earning receipts; statutory deduction covers landlord's repairs/insurance, no duplication.

holdings.text: Expenses for upkeep and repairs of the totalisator (Item 9) are deductible as necessary business outgoings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Totalisator is indispensable equipment for efficient race-course operation contributing to receipts; not mere machinery excluded under s.154(2).

holdings.text: Expenses under Items 6, 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14 are fully deductible without apportionment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenant responsible year-round for upkeep to earn profits; no lease provision shifting burden to landlord off-season; all necessary for receipts.

holdings.text: Licence fee under Bombay Race-Courses Licensing Act is fully deductible as tenant's burden; not for dual purpose.

anchor.surface_text: For the relevant year the Club had allotted Rs, 8,66,666 out of the licence fee of Rs. 13 lacs to the Bombay race-course. Counsel urged that the Club was entitled to a deduction of Rs. 4,33,333 only as the licence was for a dual purpose,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Licence granted to Club for conducting races (s.4); applied by Club; burden on conductor (tenant); Act licenses horse-racing, not premises separately.

holdings.text: Wheel tax and water tax are fully deductible without apportionment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary business expenses of Club; no basis for partial disallowance based on non-race periods.

holdings.text: Net rateable value under s.154 can be less than actual contractual rent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical tenant considers all burdens like public access obligations reducing value; actual rent may differ.

holdings.text: High Court's determination of gross rateable value Rs. 2,15,750 and net rateable value Rs. 1,94,175 under s.154 is correct; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the gross rateable value of the property would after these deductions be Rs. 2,15,750 and after deducting therefrom the statutory deduction of 10 percent. the net rateable value would come to Rs. 1,94,175

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholding deductions as proper working expenses under profits basis for hypothetical annual rent minus 10%.

anchor.surface_text: One of the earliest cases where this method was applied to undertakings which are number public utilities is the case of R. v. Verall 1 which was a case of a race- companyrse.

precedents.cited_proposition: profits basis method applied to race-course which is not a public utility

anchor.surface_text: In Sanddown Park Case 2 the Court of Appeal held that in cases where actual receipts and expenditure are accepted as relevant factors for the ascertainment of cross value, sums reflecting the tenants reasonable profit. risk and interest on capital should be together treated as a charge on the divisible profits in priority to other deductions.

precedents.cited_proposition: where actual receipts and expenditure are accepted as relevant factors for gross value, tenant's reasonable profit, risk and interest on capital are priority charges on divisible profits
precedents.cited_holding: in cases where actual receipts and expenditure are accepted as relevant factors for the ascertainment of cross value, sums reflecting the tenants reasonable profit. risk and interest on capital should be together treated as a charge on the divisible profits in priority to other deductions.

precedents.citation: Port of London Authority v. Assessment Committee 3

anchor.surface_text: as stated by Lord Birkenhead L.C. in Port of London Authority v. Assessment Committee 3  By this reckoning the amount of the gross receipts is ascertained, and from such amount are deducted the expenses of earning such receipts, the deductions provided, for by statute, interest on tenants capital and the estimated amount of tenants profit.

precedents.case_name: Port of London Authority v. Assessment Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: profits basis method consists of ascertaining gross receipts and deducting expenses, statutory deductions, interest on tenant's capital and estimated tenant's profit to arrive at indication of hypothetical rent
precedents.cited_holding: By this reckoning the amount of the gross receipts is ascertained, and from such amount are deducted the expenses of earning such receipts, the deductions provided, for by statute, interest on tenants capital and the estimated amount of tenants profit. The figure so ascertained would give the rating authority a valuable indication as to the rent which the hypothetical tenant would be likely to give for the right to occupy the hereditament in question and therefore would enable them to form an opinion as to the companyrect amount of the net annual value for the purpose of rating.
